verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord gave us the following order:
‘I have made you a light for the nations
    so that you would save people all over the world.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who were not Jews were pleased with what they heard and praised the Lord’s word. Everyone who had been prepared for everlasting life believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord spread throughout the whole region.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jews stirred up devout women of high social standing and the officials of the city. These people started to persecute Paul and Barnabas and threw them out of their territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In protest against these people, Paul and Barnabas shook the dust off their feet and went to the city of Iconium.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the disciples in Antioch continued to be full of joy and the Holy Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The same thing happened in the city of Iconium. Paul and Barnabas went into the synagogue and spoke in such a way that a large crowd of Jews and Greeks believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Jews who refused to believe stirred up some people who were not Jewish and poisoned their minds against the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas stayed in the city of Iconium for a long time. They spoke boldly about the Lord, who confirmed their message about his good will by having them perform miracles and do amazing things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Iconium were divided. Some were for the Jews, while others were for the apostles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the meantime, Paul and Barnabas found out that the non-Jewish people and the Jewish people with their rulers planned to attack them and stone them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they escaped to Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and to the surrounding territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spread the Good News there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man who was born lame was in Lystra. He was always sitting because he had never been able to walk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He listened to what Paul was saying. Paul observed him closely and saw that the man believed he could be made well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Paul said in a loud voice, “Stand up.” The man jumped up and began to walk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowds who saw what Paul had done shouted in the Lycaonian language, “The gods have come to us, and they look human.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They addressed Barnabas as Zeus and Paul as Hermes because Paul did most of the talking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zeus’ temple was at the entrance to the city. The priest of the god Zeus brought bulls with flowery wreaths around their necks to the temple gates. The priest and the crowd wanted to offer a sacrifice to Paul and Barnabas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard what was happening, they were very upset. They rushed into the crowd
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, “Men, what are you doing? We’re human beings like you. We’re spreading the Good News to you to turn you away from these worthless gods to the living God. The living God made the sky, the land, the sea, and everything in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the past God allowed all people to live as they pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet, by doing good, he has given evidence of his existence. He gives you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons. He fills you with food and your lives with happiness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although Paul and Barnabas said these things, they hardly kept the crowd from sacrificing to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Jews from the cities of Antioch and Iconium arrived in Lystra and won the people over. They tried to stone Paul to death and dragged him out of the city when they thought that he was dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when the disciples gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city.
The next day Paul and Barnabas left for the city of Derbe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spread the Good News in that city and won many disciples. Then they went back to the cities of Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch (which is in Pisidia).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They strengthened the disciples in these cities and encouraged the disciples to remain faithful. Paul and Barnabas told them, “We must suffer a lot to enter the kingdom of God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had the disciples in each church choose spiritual leaders, and with prayer and fasting they entrusted the leaders to the Lord in whom they believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had gone through Pisidia, they went to Pamphylia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spoke the message in the city of Perga and went to the city of Attalia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Attalia they took a boat and headed home to the city of Antioch in Syria. (In Antioch they had been entrusted to God’s care for the work they had now finished.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived, they called the members of the church together. They reported everything God had done through them, especially that he had given people who were not Jewish the opportunity to believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They stayed for a long time with these disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men came from Judea and started to teach believers that people can’t be saved unless they are circumcised as Moses’ Teachings require.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas had a fierce dispute with these men. So Paul and Barnabas and some of the others were sent to Jerusalem to see the apostles and spiritual leaders about this claim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The church sent Paul and Barnabas to Jerusalem. As they were going through Phoenicia and Samaria, they told the whole story of how non-Jewish people were turning to God. This story brought great joy to all the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The church in Jerusalem, the apostles, and the spiritual leaders welcomed Paul and Barnabas when they arrived. Paul and Barnabas reported everything that God had done through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some believers from the party of the Pharisees stood up and said, “People who are not Jewish must be circumcised and ordered to follow Moses’ Teachings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The apostles and spiritual leaders met to consider this statement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a lot of debating, Peter stood up and said to them, “Brothers, you know what happened some time ago. God chose me so that people who aren’t Jewish could hear the Good News and believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God, who knows everyone’s thoughts, showed that he approved of people who aren’t Jewish by giving them the Holy Spirit as he gave the Holy Spirit to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God doesn’t discriminate between Jewish and non-Jewish people. He has cleansed non-Jewish people through faith as he has cleansed us Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So why are you testing God? You’re putting a burden on the disciples, a burden neither our ancestors nor we can carry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We certainly believe that the Lord Yeshua saves us the same way that he saves them—through his kindness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole crowd was silent. They listened to Barnabas and Paul tell about all the miracles and amazing things that God had done through them among non-Jewish people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they finished speaking, James responded, “Brothers, listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Simon has explained how God first showed his concern by taking from non-Jewish people those who would honor his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This agrees with what the prophets said. Scripture says,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Afterwards, I will return.
    I will set up David’s fallen tent again.
    I will restore its ruined places again.
    I will set it up again
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that the survivors and all the people who aren’t Jewish
    over whom my name is spoken,
        may search for the Lord, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is the one who will do these things that have always been known!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So I’ve decided that we shouldn’t trouble non-Jewish people who are turning to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, we should write a letter telling them to keep away from things polluted by false gods, from sexual sins, from eating the meat of strangled animals, and from eating bloody meat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, Moses’ words have been spread to every city for generations. His teachings are read in synagogues on every day of worship.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the apostles, the spiritual leaders, and the whole church decided to choose some of their men to send with Paul and Barnabas to the city of Antioch. They chose Judas (called Barsabbas) and Silas, who were leaders among the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They wrote this letter for them to deliver:
From the apostles and the spiritual leaders, your brothers.
To their non-Jewish brothers and sisters in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia.
Dear brothers and sisters,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have heard that some individuals who came from us have confused you with statements that disturb you. We did not authorize these men to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we have come to a unanimous decision that we should choose men and send them to you with our dear Barnabas and Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barnabas and Paul have dedicated their lives to our Lord, the one named Yeshua Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have sent Judas and Silas to report to you on our decision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Holy Spirit and we have agreed not to place any additional burdens on you. Do only what is necessary
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
by keeping away from food sacrificed to false gods, from eating bloody meat, from eating the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual sins. If you avoid these things, you will be doing what’s right.
Farewell!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men were sent on their way and arrived in the city of Antioch. They gathered the congregation together and delivered the letter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people read the letter, they were pleased with the encouragement it brought them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judas and Silas, who were also prophets, spoke a long time to encourage and strengthen the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Judas and Silas had stayed in Antioch for some time, the congregation sent them back to Jerusalem with friendly greetings to those who had sent them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch. They and many others taught people about the Lord’s word and spread the Good News.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a while Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s go back to every city where we spread the Lord’s word. We’ll visit the believers to see how they’re doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barnabas wanted to take John Mark along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Paul didn’t think it was right to take a person like him along. John Mark had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not gone with them to work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas disagreed so sharply that they parted ways. Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed to the island of Cyprus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul chose Silas and left after the believers entrusted him to the Lord’s care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul went through the provinces of Syria and Cilicia and strengthened the churches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul arrived in the city of Derbe and then went to Lystra, where a disciple named Timothy lived. Timothy’s mother was a Jewish believer, but his father was Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The believers in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of Timothy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted Timothy to go with him. So he circumcised him because of the Jews who lived in those places and because he knew that Timothy’s father was Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they went through the cities, they told people about the decisions that the apostles and spiritual leaders in Jerusalem had made for the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew in numbers every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Silas went through the regions of Phrygia and Galatia because the Holy Spirit kept them from speaking the word in the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the province of Mysia and tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Yeshua wouldn’t allow this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they passed by Mysia and went to the city of Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Paul had a vision of a man from Macedonia. The man urged Paul, “Come to Macedonia to help us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Paul had seen the vision, we immediately looked for a way to go to Macedonia. We concluded that God had called us to tell the people of Macedonia about the Good News.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we took a ship from Troas and sailed straight to the island of Samothrace. The next day we sailed to the city of Neapolis,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and from there we went to the city of Philippi. Philippi is a leading city in that part of Macedonia, and it is a Roman colony. We were in this city for a number of days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day of worship we went out of the city to a place along the river where we thought Jewish people gathered for prayer. We sat down and began talking to the women who had gathered there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A woman named Lydia was present. She was a convert to Judaism from the city of Thyatira and sold purple dye for a living. She was listening because the Lord made her willing to pay attention to what Paul said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Lydia and her family were baptized, she invited us to stay at her home. She said, “If you’re convinced that I believe in the Lord, then stay at my home.” She insisted. So we did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day when we were going to the place of prayer, a female servant met us. She was possessed by an evil spirit that told fortunes. She made a lot of money for her owners by telling fortunes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She used to follow Paul and shout, “These men are servants of the Most High God. They’re telling you how you can be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She kept doing this for many days. Paul became annoyed, turned to the evil spirit, and said, “I command you in the name of Yeshua Christ to come out of her!”
As Paul said this, the evil spirit left her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her owners realized that their hope of making money was gone, they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them to the authorities in the public square.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In front of the Roman officials, they said, “These men are stirring up a lot of trouble in our city. They’re Jews,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they’re advocating customs that we can’t accept or practice as Roman citizens.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd joined in the attack against Paul and Silas. Then the officials tore the clothes off Paul and Silas and ordered the guards to beat them with sticks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had hit Paul and Silas many times, they threw them in jail and ordered the jailer to keep them under tight security.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the jailer followed these orders and put Paul and Silas into solitary confinement with their feet in leg irons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Around midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns of praise to God. The other prisoners were listening to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, a violent earthquake shook the foundations of the jail. All the doors immediately flew open, and all the prisoners’ chains came loose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer woke up and saw the prison doors open. Thinking the prisoners had escaped, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul shouted as loudly as he could, “Don’t hurt yourself! We’re all here!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer asked for torches and rushed into the jail. He was trembling as he knelt in front of Paul and Silas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took Paul and Silas outside and asked, “Sirs, what do I have to do to be saved?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “Believe in the Lord Yeshua, and you and your family will be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spoke the Lord’s word to the jailer and everyone in his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that hour of the night, the jailer washed Paul and Silas’ wounds. The jailer and his entire family were baptized immediately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took Paul and Silas upstairs into his home and gave them something to eat. He and his family were thrilled to be believers in God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning the Roman officials sent guards who told the jailer, “You can release those men now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer reported this order to Paul by saying, “The officials have sent word to release you. So you can leave peacefully now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul told the guards, “Roman officials have had us beaten publicly without a trial and have thrown us in jail, even though we’re Roman citizens. Now are they going to throw us out secretly? There’s no way they’re going to get away with that! Have them escort us out!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The guards reported to the officials what Paul had said. When the Roman officials heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens, they were afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the officials went to the jail and apologized to Paul and Silas. As the officials escorted Paul and Silas out of the jail, they asked them to leave the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul and Silas left the jail, they went to Lydia’s house. They met with the believers, encouraged them, and then left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Silas traveled through the cities of Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to the city of Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As usual, Paul went into the synagogue. On three consecutive days of worship, he had discussions about Scripture with the synagogue members.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He explained and showed them that the Messiah had to suffer, die, and come back to life, and that Yeshua, the person he talked about, was this Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Jews were persuaded to join Paul and Silas, especially a large group of Greeks who had converted to Judaism and the wives of many prominent men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Jews became jealous. They took some low-class characters who hung around the public square, formed a mob, and started a riot in the city. They attacked Jason’s home and searched it for Paul and Silas in order to bring them out to the crowd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they didn’t find Paul and Silas, they dragged Jason and some other believers in front of the city officials. They shouted, “Those men who have made trouble all over the world are now here in Thessalonica,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jason has welcomed them as his guests. All of them oppose the emperor’s decrees by saying that there is another king, whose name is Yeshua.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd and the officials were upset when they heard this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after they had made Jason and the others post bond, they let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Immediately when night came, the believers sent Paul and Silas to the city of Berea.
When Paul and Silas arrived in the city of Berea, they entered the synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Berea were more open-minded than the people of Thessalonica. They were very willing to receive God’s message, and every day they carefully examined the Scriptures to see if what Paul said was true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of them became believers, and quite a number of them were prominent Greek men and women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews in Thessalonica found out that Paul was also spreading God’s word in Berea, they went there to upset and confuse the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The believers immediately sent Paul to the seacoast, but Silas and Timothy stayed in Berea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men who escorted Paul took him all the way to the city of Athens. When the men left Athens, they took instructions back to Silas and Timothy to join Paul as soon as possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Paul was waiting for Silas and Timothy in Athens, he saw that the city had statues of false gods everywhere. This upset him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He held discussions in the synagogue with Jews and converts to Judaism. He also held discussions every day in the public square with anyone who happened to be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers had discussions with him. Some asked, “What is this babbling fool trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be speaking about foreign gods.” The philosophers said these things because Paul was telling the Good News about Yeshua and saying that people would come back to life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they brought Paul to the city court, the Areopagus, and asked, “Could you tell us these new ideas that you’re teaching?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the things you say sound strange to us. So we would like to know what they mean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who lived in Athens looked for opportunities to tell or hear something new and unusual.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul stood in the middle of the court and said, “Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I was going through your city and looking closely at the objects you worship, I noticed an altar with this written on it: ‘To an unknown god.’ I’m telling you about the unknown god you worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The God who made the universe and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth. He doesn’t live in shrines made by humans,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he isn’t served by humans as if he needed anything. He gives everyone life, breath, and everything they have.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From one man he has made every nation of humanity to live all over the earth. He has given them the seasons of the year and the boundaries within which to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has done this so that they would look for God, somehow reach for him, and find him. In fact, he is never far from any one of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Certainly, we live, move, and exist because of him. As some of your poets have said, ‘We are God’s children.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if we are God’s children, we shouldn’t think that the divine being is like an image made from gold, silver, or stone, an image that is the product of human imagination and skill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God overlooked the times when people didn’t know any better. But now he commands everyone everywhere to turn to him and change the way they think and act.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has set a day when he is going to judge the world with justice, and he will use a man he has appointed to do this. God has given proof to everyone that he will do this by bringing that man back to life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of the court heard that a person had come back to life, some began joking about it, while others said, “We’ll hear you talk about this some other time.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With this response, Paul left the court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men joined him and became believers. With them were Dionysius, who was a member of the court, and a woman named Damaris, and some other people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Paul left Athens and went to the city of Corinth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Corinth he met a Jewish man named Aquila and his wife Priscilla. Aquila had been born in Pontus, and they had recently come from Italy because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to visit them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and because they made tents for a living as he did, he stayed with them and they worked together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On every day of worship, Paul would discuss Scripture in the synagogue. He tried to win over Jews and Greeks who had converted to Judaism.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul devoted all his time to teaching the word of God. He assured the Jews that Yeshua is the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they opposed him and insulted him. So Paul shook the dust from his clothes and told them, “You’re responsible for your own death. I’m innocent. From now on I’m going to people who are not Jewish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he left the synagogue and went to the home of a man named Titius Justus, who was a convert to Judaism. His house was next door to the synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The synagogue leader Crispus and his whole family believed in the Lord. Many Corinthians who heard Paul believed and were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night the Lord said to Paul in a vision, “Don’t be afraid to speak out! Don’t be silent!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m with you. No one will attack you or harm you. I have many people in this city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul lived in Corinth for a year and a half and taught the word of God to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Gallio was governor of Greece, the Jews had one thought in mind. They attacked Paul and brought him to court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “This man is persuading people to worship God in ways that are against Moses’ Teachings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul was about to answer when Gallio said to the Jews, “If there were some kind of misdemeanor or crime involved, reason would demand that I put up with you Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But since you’re disputing words, names, and your own teachings, you’ll have to take care of that yourselves. I don’t want to be a judge who gets involved in those things.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gallio had them forced out of his court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the governor’s officers took Sosthenes, the synagogue leader, and beat him in front of the court. But Gallio couldn’t have cared less.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After staying in Corinth quite a while longer, Paul left for Ephesus. Priscilla and Aquila went with him. In the city of Cenchrea, Aquila had his hair cut, since he had taken a vow. From Cenchrea they took a boat headed for Syria
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and arrived in the city of Ephesus, where Paul left Priscilla and Aquila. Paul went into the synagogue and had a discussion with the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews asked him to stay longer, but he refused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As he left, he told them, “I’ll come back to visit you if God wants me to.”
Paul took a boat from Ephesus
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and arrived in the city of Caesarea. He went to Jerusalem, greeted the church, and went back to the city of Antioch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending some time in Antioch, Paul went through the regions of Galatia and Phrygia, where he strengthened the faith of all the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A Jew named Apollos, who had been born in Alexandria, arrived in the city of Ephesus. He was an eloquent speaker and knew how to use the Scriptures in a powerful way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had been instructed in the Lord’s way and spoke enthusiastically. He accurately taught about Yeshua but knew only about the baptism John performed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him home with them and explained God’s way to him more accurately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Apollos wanted to travel to Greece, the believers in Ephesus encouraged him. They wrote to the disciples in Greece to tell them to welcome him. When he arrived in Greece, God’s kindness enabled him to help the believers a great deal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In public Apollos helped them by clearly showing from the Scriptures that Yeshua is the Messiah and that the Jews were wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the interior provinces to get to the city of Ephesus. He met some disciples in Ephesus
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you became believers?”
They answered him, “No, we’ve never even heard of the Holy Spirit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Paul asked them, “What kind of baptism did you have?”
They answered, “John’s baptism.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “John’s baptism was a baptism of repentance. John told people to believe in Yeshua, who was coming later.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Yeshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul placed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came to them, and they began to talk in other languages and to speak what God had revealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About twelve men were in the group.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For three months Paul would go into the synagogue and speak boldly. He had discussions with people to convince them about the kingdom of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when some people became stubborn, refused to believe, and had nothing good to say in front of the crowd about the way of Christ, he left them. He took his disciples and held daily discussions in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This continued for two years so that all the Jews and Greeks who lived in the province of Asia heard the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God worked unusual miracles through Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People would take handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched Paul’s skin to those who were sick. Their sicknesses would be cured, and evil spirits would leave them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Jews used to travel from place to place and force evil spirits out of people. They tried to use the name of the Lord Yeshua to force evil spirits out of those who were possessed. These Jews would say, “I order you to come out in the name of Yeshua, whom Paul talks about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, were doing this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the evil spirit answered them, “I know Yeshua, and I’m acquainted with Paul, but who are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man possessed by the evil spirit attacked them. He beat them up so badly that they ran out of that house naked and wounded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Jews and Greeks living in the city of Ephesus heard about this. All of them were filled with awe for the name of the Lord Yeshua and began to speak very highly about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many believers openly admitted their involvement with magical spells and told all the details.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of those who were involved in the occult gathered their books and burned them in front of everyone. They added up the cost of these books and found that they were worth 50,000 silver coins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this powerful way the word of the Lord was spreading and gaining strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all these things had happened, Paul decided to go to Jerusalem by traveling through Macedonia and Greece. He said, “After I have been there, I must see Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he stayed longer in the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During that time a serious disturbance concerning the way of Christ broke out in the city of Ephesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Demetrius, a silversmith, was in the business of making silver models of the temple of Artemis. His business brought a huge profit for the men who worked for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called a meeting of his workers and others who did similar work. Demetrius said, “Men, you know that we’re earning a good income from this business,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you see and hear what this man Paul has done. He has won over a large crowd that follows him not only in Ephesus but also throughout the province of Asia. He tells people that gods made by humans are not gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There’s a danger that people will discredit our line of work, and there’s a danger that people will think that the temple of the great goddess Artemis is nothing. Then she whom all Asia and the rest of the world worship will be robbed of her glory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Demetrius’ workers and the others heard this, they became furious and began shouting, “Artemis of the Ephesians is great!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The confusion spread throughout the city, and the people had one thought in mind as they rushed into the theater. They grabbed Gaius and Aristarchus, the Macedonians who traveled with Paul, and they dragged the two men into the theater with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted to go into the crowd, but his disciples wouldn’t let him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even some officials who were from the province of Asia and who were Paul’s friends sent messengers to urge him not to risk going into the theater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some people shouted one thing while others shouted something else. The crowd was confused. Most of the people didn’t even know why they had come together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some people concluded that Alexander was the cause, so the Jews pushed him to the front. Alexander motioned with his hand to quiet the people because he wanted to defend himself in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they recognized that Alexander was a Jew, everyone started to shout in unison, “Artemis of the Ephesians is great!” They kept doing this for about two hours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city clerk finally quieted the crowd. Then he said, “Citizens of Ephesus, everyone knows that this city of the Ephesians is the keeper of the temple of the great Artemis. Everyone knows that Ephesus is the keeper of the statue that fell down from Zeus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one can deny this. So you have to be quiet and not do anything foolish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men you brought here don’t rob temples or insult our goddess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If Demetrius and the men who work for him have a legal complaint against anyone, we have special days and officials to hold court. That’s where they should bring charges against each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you want anything else, you must settle the matter in a legal assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this moment we run the risk of being accused of rioting today for no reason. We won’t be able to explain this mob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After saying this, he dismissed the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the uproar was over, Paul sent for the disciples, encouraged them, said goodbye, and left for Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went through that region and spoke many words of encouragement to the people. Then he went to Greece
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and stayed there for three months.
When Paul was going to board a ship for Syria, he found out that the Jews were plotting to kill him. So he decided to go back through Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sopater (son of Pyrrhus) from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia accompanied Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these men went ahead and were waiting for us in Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Festival of Unleavened Bread, we boarded a ship at Philippi. Five days later we joined them in Troas and stayed there for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On Sunday we met to break bread. Paul was discussing Scripture with the people. Since he intended to leave the next day, he kept talking until midnight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Many lamps were lit in the upstairs room where we were meeting.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A young man named Eutychus was sitting in a window. As Paul was talking on and on, Eutychus was gradually falling asleep. Finally, overcome by sleep, he fell from the third story and was dead when they picked him up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul went to him, took him into his arms, and said, “Don’t worry! He’s alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eutychus went upstairs again, broke the bread, and ate. Paul talked with the people for a long time, until sunrise, and then left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people took the boy home. They were greatly relieved that he was alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We went ahead to the ship and sailed for the city of Assos. At Assos, we were going to pick up Paul. He had made these arrangements, since he had planned to walk overland to Assos.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul met us in Assos, we took him on board and went to the city of Mitylene.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed from there. On the following day we approached the island of Chios. The next day we went by the island of Samos, and on the next day we arrived at the city of Miletus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus to avoid spending time in the province of Asia. He was in a hurry to get to Jerusalem for the day of Pentecost, if that was possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Miletus Paul sent messengers to the city of Ephesus and called the spiritual leaders of the church to meet with him in Miletus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were with him, he said to them, “You know how I spent all my time with you from the first day I arrived in the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I humbly served the Lord, often with tears in my eyes. I served the Lord during the difficult times I went through when the Jews plotted against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I didn’t avoid telling you anything that would help you, and I didn’t avoid teaching you publicly and from house to house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I warned Jews and Greeks to change the way they think and act and to believe in our Lord Yeshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am determined to go to Jerusalem now. I don’t know what will happen to me there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the Holy Spirit warns me in every city that imprisonment and suffering are waiting for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I don’t place any value on my own life. I want to finish the race I’m running. I want to carry out the mission I received from the Lord Yeshua—the mission of testifying to the Good News of God’s kindness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now I know that none of you whom I told about the kingdom of God will see me again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I declare to you today that I am not responsible for the spiritual death of any of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I didn’t avoid telling you the whole plan of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention to yourselves and to the entire flock in which the Holy Spirit has placed you as bishops to be shepherds for God’s church which he acquired with his own blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that fierce wolves will come to you after I leave, and they won’t spare the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of your own men will come forward and say things that distort the truth. They will do this to lure disciples into following them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So be alert! Remember that I instructed each of you for three years, day and night, at times with tears in my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am now entrusting you to God and to his message that tells how kind he is. That message can help you grow and can give you the inheritance that is shared by all of God’s holy people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I never wanted anyone’s silver, gold, or clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that I worked to support myself and those who were with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have given you an example that by working hard like this we should help the weak. We should remember the words that the Lord Yeshua said, ‘Giving gifts is more satisfying than receiving them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had finished speaking, he knelt down and prayed with all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone cried a lot as they put their arms around Paul and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thought of not seeing Paul again hurt them most of all. Then they took Paul to the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we finally left them, we sailed straight to the island of Cos. The next day we sailed to the island of Rhodes and from there to the city of Patara.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Patara, we found a ship that was going to Phoenicia, so we went aboard and sailed away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We could see the island of Cyprus as we passed it on our left and sailed to Syria. We landed at the city of Tyre, where the ship was to unload its cargo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Tyre we searched for the disciples. After we found them, we stayed there for seven days. The Spirit had the disciples tell Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When our time was up, we started on our way. All of them with their wives and children accompanied us out of the city. We knelt on the beach, prayed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said goodbye to each other. Then we went aboard the ship, and the disciples went back home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our sea travel ended when we sailed from Tyre to the city of Ptolemais. We greeted the believers in Ptolemais and spent the day with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we went to Philip’s home in Caesarea and stayed with him. He was a missionary and one of the seven men who helped the apostles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Philip had four unmarried daughters who had the ability to speak what God had revealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After we had been there for a number of days, a prophet named Agabus arrived from Judea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During his visit he took Paul’s belt and tied his own feet and hands with it. Then he said, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘This is how the Jews in Jerusalem will tie up the man who owns this belt. Then they will hand him over to people who are not Jewish.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we heard this, we and the believers who lived there begged Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul replied, “Why are you crying like this and breaking my heart? I’m ready not only to be tied up in Jerusalem but also to die there for the sake of the Lord, the one named Yeshua.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul could not be persuaded, we dropped the issue and said, “May the Lord’s will be done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, we got ready to go to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us. They took us to Mnason’s home, where we would be staying. Mnason was from the island of Cyprus and was one of the first disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the believers welcomed us warmly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Paul went with us to visit James. All the spiritual leaders were present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After greeting them, Paul related everything God had done through his work with non-Jewish people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the spiritual leaders heard about everything, they praised God. They said to Paul, “You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews are now believers, and all of them are deeply committed to Moses’ Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they have been told that you teach all the Jews living among non-Jewish people to abandon Moses. They claim that you tell them not to circumcise their children or follow Jewish customs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What should we do about this? They will certainly hear that you’re in town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So follow our advice. We have four men who have made a vow to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take these men, go through the purification ceremony with them, and pay the expenses to shave their heads. Then everyone will know that what they’ve been told about you isn’t true. Instead, they’ll see that you carefully follow Moses’ Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To clarify this matter we have written non-Jewish believers a letter with our decision. We told them that they should not eat food sacrificed to false gods, bloody meat, or the meat of strangled animals. They also should not commit sexual sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, Paul took the men and went through the purification ceremony with them. Then he went into the temple courtyard to announce the time when the purification would be over and the sacrifice would be offered for each of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seven days were almost over, the Jews from the province of Asia saw Paul in the temple courtyard. They stirred up the whole crowd and grabbed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they began shouting, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere to turn against the Jewish people, Moses’ Teachings, and this temple. He has even brought Greeks into the temple courtyard and has made this holy place unclean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had seen Trophimus from Ephesus with him in the city earlier and thought Paul had taken him into the temple courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole city was in chaos, and a mob formed. The mob grabbed Paul and dragged him out of the temple courtyard. The courtyard doors were immediately shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the people were trying to kill Paul, the officer in charge of the Roman soldiers received a report that all Jerusalem was rioting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately, he took some soldiers and officers and charged the crowd. When the crowd saw the officer and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the officer went to Paul, grabbed him, and ordered him to be tied up with two chains.
The officer asked who Paul was and what he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the crowd shouted one thing, while others shouted something else. The officer couldn’t get any facts because of the noise and confusion, so he ordered Paul to be taken into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul came to the stairs of the barracks, the crowd was so violent that the soldiers had to carry him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The mob was behind them shouting, “Kill him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the soldiers were about to take Paul into the barracks, he asked the officer, “May I say something to you?”
The officer replied to Paul, “Can you speak Greek?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aren’t you the Egyptian who started a revolution not long ago and led four thousand terrorists into the desert?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul answered, “I’m a Jew, a citizen from the well-known city of Tarsus in Cilicia. I’m asking you to let me talk to the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officer gave Paul permission to speak. So Paul stood on the stairs of the barracks and motioned with his hand for the people to be quiet. When the mob was silent, Paul spoke to them in the Hebrew language.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Brothers and fathers, listen as I now present my case to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the mob heard him speak to them in Hebrew, they became even more quiet. Then Paul continued,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m a Jew. I was born and raised in the city of Tarsus in Cilicia and received my education from Gamaliel here in Jerusalem. My education was in the strict laws handed down by our ancestors. I was as devoted to God as all of you are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I persecuted people who followed the way of Christ: I tied up men and women and put them into prison until they were executed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief priest and the entire council of our leaders can prove that I did this. In fact, they even gave me letters to take to the Jewish community in the city of Damascus. I was going there to tie up believers and bring them back to Jerusalem to punish them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But as I was on my way and approaching the city of Damascus about noon, a bright light from heaven suddenly flashed around me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice asking me, ‘Saul! Saul! Why are you persecuting me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I answered, ‘Who are you, sir?’
“The person told me, ‘I’m Yeshua from Nazareth, the one you’re persecuting.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The men who were with me saw the light but didn’t understand what the person who was speaking to me said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then I asked, ‘What do you want me to do, Lord?’
“The Lord told me, ‘Get up! Go into the city of Damascus, and you’ll be told everything I’ve arranged for you to do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I was blind because the light had been so bright. So the men who were with me led me into the city of Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “A man named Ananias lived in Damascus. He was a devout person who followed Moses’ Teachings. All the Jews living in Damascus spoke highly of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to me, stood beside me, and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight!’ At that moment my sight came back and I could see Ananias.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Ananias said, ‘The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will, to see the one who has God’s approval, and to hear him speak to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be his witness and will tell everyone what you have seen and heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What are you waiting for now? Get up! Be baptized, and have your sins washed away as you call on his name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After that, I returned to Jerusalem. While I was praying in the temple courtyard, I fell into a trance
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw the Lord. He told me, ‘Hurry! Get out of Jerusalem immediately. The people here won’t accept your testimony about me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I said, ‘Lord, people here know that I went from synagogue to synagogue to imprison and whip those who believe in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Stephen, who witnessed about you, was being killed, I was standing there. I approved of his death and guarded the coats of those who were murdering him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But the Lord told me, ‘Go! I’ll send you on a mission. You’ll go far away to people who aren’t Jewish.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Up to that point the mob listened. Then they began to shout, “Kill him! The world doesn’t need a man like this. He shouldn’t have been allowed to live this long!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The mob was yelling, taking off their coats, and throwing dirt into the air.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the officer ordered the soldiers to take Paul into the barracks and told them to question Paul as they whipped him. The officer wanted to find out why the people were yelling at Paul like this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the soldiers had Paul stretch out to tie him to the whipping post with the straps, Paul asked the sergeant who was standing there, “Is it legal for you to whip a Roman citizen who hasn’t had a trial?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sergeant heard this, he reported it to his commanding officer. The sergeant asked him, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The officer went to Paul and asked him, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
Paul answered, “Yes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The officer replied, “I paid a lot of money to become a Roman citizen.”
Paul replied, “But I was born a Roman citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately, the soldiers who were going to question Paul stepped away from him. The officer was afraid when he found out that he had tied up a Roman citizen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officer wanted to find out exactly what accusation the Jews had against Paul. So the officer released Paul the next day and ordered the chief priests and the entire Jewish council to meet. Then the officer brought Paul and had him stand in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul stared at the Jewish council and said, “Brothers, my relationship with God has always given me a perfectly clear conscience.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief priest Ananias ordered the men standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul said to him, “God will strike you, you hypocrite! You sit there and judge me by Moses’ Teachings and yet you break those teachings by ordering these men to strike me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men standing near Paul said to him, “You’re insulting God’s chief priest!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul answered, “Brothers, I didn’t know that he is the chief priest. After all, Scripture says, ‘Don’t speak evil about a ruler of your people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul saw that some of them were Sadducees and others were Pharisees, he shouted in the council, “Brothers, I’m a Pharisee and a descendant of Pharisees. I’m on trial because I expect that the dead will come back to life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul said that, the Pharisees and Sadducees began to quarrel, and the men in the meeting were divided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Sadducees say that the dead won’t come back to life and that angels and spirits don’t exist. The Pharisees believe in all these things.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The shouting became very loud. Some of the experts in Moses’ Teachings were Pharisees who argued their position forcefully. They said, “We don’t find anything wrong with this man. Maybe a spirit or an angel actually spoke to him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The quarrel was becoming violent, and the officer was afraid that they would tear Paul to pieces. So the officer ordered his soldiers to drag Paul back to the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord stood near Paul the next night and said to him, “Don’t lose your courage! You’ve told the truth about me in Jerusalem. Now you must tell the truth about me in Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning the Jews formed a conspiracy. They asked God to curse them if they ate or drank anything before they had killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: More than forty men took part in this plot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the chief priests and leaders of the people and said, “We’ve asked God to curse us if we taste any food before we’ve killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here’s our plan: You and the council must go to the Roman officer on the pretext that you need more information from Paul. You have to make it look as though you want to get more accurate information about him. We’ll be ready to kill him before he gets to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul’s nephew heard about the ambush. He entered the barracks and told Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul called one of the sergeants and told him, “Take this young man to the officer. He has something to tell him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sergeant took the young man to the officer and said, “The prisoner Paul called me. He asked me to bring this young man to you because he has something to tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officer took the young man by the arm, went where they could be alone, and asked him, “What do you have to tell me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man answered, “The Jews have planned to ask you to bring Paul to the Jewish council tomorrow. They’re going to make it look as though they want more accurate information about him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let them persuade you to do this. More than forty of them are planning to ambush him. They have asked God to curse them if they eat or drink anything before they have murdered him. They are ready now and are expecting you to promise that you will bring Paul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officer dismissed the young man and ordered him not to tell this information to anyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officer summoned two of his sergeants and told them, “I want 200 infantrymen, 70 soldiers on horseback, and 200 soldiers with spears. Have them ready to go to Caesarea at nine o’clock tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Provide an animal for Paul to ride, and take him safely to Governor Felix.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officer wrote a letter to the governor with the following message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Claudius Lysias sends greetings to Your Excellency, Governor Felix:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews had seized this man and were going to murder him. When I found out that he was a Roman citizen, I went with my soldiers to rescue him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wanted to know what they had against him. So I took him to their Jewish council
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and found their accusations had to do with disputes about their own laws. He wasn’t accused of anything for which he deserved to die or to be put into prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since I was informed that there was a plot against this man, I immediately sent him to you. I have also ordered his accusers to state their case against him in front of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the infantrymen did as they had been ordered. They took Paul to the city of Antipatris during the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They returned to their barracks the next day and let the soldiers on horseback travel with Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the soldiers arrived in the city of Caesarea with Paul, they delivered the letter to the governor and handed Paul over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the governor had read the letter, he asked Paul which province he was from. When he found out that Paul was from the province of Cilicia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said, “I’ll hear your case when your accusers arrive.” Then the governor gave orders to keep Paul under guard in Herod’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Five days later the chief priest Ananias went to the city of Caesarea with some leaders of the people and an attorney named Tertullus. They reported to the governor their charges against Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had been summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him. He said to Felix, “Your Excellency, through your wise leadership we have lasting peace and reforms that benefit the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We appreciate what you’ve done in every way and in every place, and we want to thank you very much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I don’t want to keep you too long. Please listen to us. We will be brief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have found this man to be a troublemaker. He starts quarrels among all Jews throughout the world. He’s a ringleader of the Nazarene sect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also entered the temple courtyard in a way that violates our tradition. So we arrested him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you cross-examine him, you’ll be able to find out from him that our accusations are true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews supported Tertullus’ accusations and asserted that everything Tertullus said was true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The governor motioned for Paul to speak. Paul responded, “I know that you have been a judge over this nation for many years. So I’m pleased to present my case to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can verify for yourself that I went to Jerusalem to worship no more than twelve days ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one found me having a discussion with anyone in the temple courtyard or stirring up a crowd in the synagogues throughout the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These people cannot even prove their accusations to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I’ll admit to you that I’m a follower of the way of Christ, which they call a sect. This means that I serve our ancestors’ God and believe everything written in Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I hope for the same thing my accusers do, that people with God’s approval and those without it will come back to life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With this belief I always do my best to have a clear conscience in the sight of God and people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After many years I have come back to my people and brought gifts for the poor and offerings for God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My accusers found me in the temple courtyard doing these things after I had gone through the purification ceremony. No crowd or noisy mob was present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some Jews from the province of Asia were there. They should be here in front of you to accuse me if they have anything against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Otherwise, these men who are accusing me should tell what I was charged with when I stood in front of their council.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They could accuse me of only one thing. As I stood among them, I shouted, ‘I’m being tried in front of you because I believe that the dead will come back to life.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Felix knew the way of Christ rather well, so he adjourned the trial. He told them, “When the officer Lysias arrives, I’ll decide your case.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Felix ordered the sergeant to guard Paul but to let him have some freedom and to let his friends take care of his needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some days later Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him talk about faith in Christ Yeshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Paul discussed the subjects of God’s approval, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became afraid and said, “That’s enough for now. You can go. When I find time, I’ll send for you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time, Felix was hoping that Paul would give him some money. For that reason, Felix would send for Paul rather often to have friendly conversations with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two years passed. Then Porcius Festus took Felix’s place. (Since Felix wanted to do the Jews a favor, he left Paul in prison.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days after Festus took over his duties in the province of Judea, he went from the city of Caesarea to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief priests and the other important Jewish leaders informed Festus about their charges against Paul. They were urging
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus to do them the favor of having Paul brought to Jerusalem. The Jews had a plan to ambush and kill Paul as he traveled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus replied that he would be returning to Caesarea soon and would keep Paul there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told them, “Have your authorities come to Caesarea with me and accuse him there if the man has done something wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus stayed in Jerusalem for eight or ten days at the most and then returned to Caesarea. The next day Festus took his place in court and summoned Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul entered the room, the Jews who had come from Jerusalem surrounded him. They made a lot of serious accusations that they couldn’t prove.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul defended himself by saying, “I haven’t broken any Jewish law or done anything against the temple or the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Festus wanted to do the Jews a favor. So he asked Paul, “Are you willing to go to Jerusalem to be tried there on these charges with me as your judge?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “I am standing in the emperor’s court where I must be tried. I haven’t done anything wrong to the Jews, as you know very well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I am guilty and have done something wrong for which I deserve the death penalty, I don’t reject the idea of dying. But if their accusations are untrue, no one can hand me over to them as a favor. I appeal my case to the emperor!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus discussed the appeal with his advisers and then replied to Paul, “You have appealed your case to the emperor, so you’ll go to the emperor!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later King Agrippa and Bernice came to the city of Caesarea to welcome Festus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since they were staying there for a number of days, Festus told the king about Paul’s case.
Festus said, “Felix left a man here in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I went to Jerusalem, the chief priests and the Jewish leaders brought me some information about him and asked me to condemn him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I replied to them, ‘That’s not the Roman way of doing things. A person can’t be sentenced as a favor. Before he is sentenced, he must face his accusers and have a chance to defend himself against their accusation.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So the Jewish leaders came to Caesarea with me. The next day I immediately convened court and summoned the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his accusers stood up, they didn’t accuse him of the crimes I was expecting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were disputing with him about their own religion and about some man named Yeshua who had died. But Paul claimed that Yeshua is alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their debate about these things left me puzzled. So I asked Paul if he would like to go to Jerusalem to have his case heard there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul appealed his case. He asked to be held in prison and to have His Majesty the Emperor decide his case. So I ordered him to be held in prison until I could send him to the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Agrippa told Festus, “I would like to hear the man.”
Festus replied, “You’ll hear him tomorrow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Agrippa and Bernice entered the auditorium with a lot of fanfare. Roman army officers and the most important men of the city entered the auditorium with them. Festus gave the order, and Paul was brought into the auditorium.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Festus said, “King Agrippa and everyone who is present with us! All the Jews in Jerusalem and Caesarea have talked to me about this man you see in front of you. They shout that he must not be allowed to live any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I don’t think that he has done anything to deserve the death penalty. But since he made an appeal to His Majesty the Emperor, I have decided to send him to Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I don’t have anything reliable to write our emperor about him. So I have brought him to all of you, and especially to you, King Agrippa. Then I’ll have something to write after he is cross-examined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I find it ridiculous to send a prisoner to Rome when I can’t specify any charges against him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Agrippa said to Paul, “You’re free to speak for yourself.”
Paul acknowledged King Agrippa and then began his defense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “King Agrippa, I think I’m fortunate today to stand in front of you and defend myself against every charge that the Jews brought against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I say this since you are especially familiar with every custom and controversy in Judaism. So I ask you to listen patiently to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All the Jews know how I lived the earliest days of my youth with my own people and in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ve known me for a long time and can testify, if they’re willing, that I followed the strictest party of our religion. They know that I lived my life as a Pharisee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m on trial now because I expect God to keep the promise that he made to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our twelve tribes expect this promise to be kept as they worship with intense devotion day and night. Your Majesty, the Jews are making accusations against me because I expect God to keep his promise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why do all of you refuse to believe that God can bring dead people back to life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I used to think that I had to do a lot of things to oppose the one named Yeshua of Nazareth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is what I did in Jerusalem. By the authority I received from the chief priests, I locked many Christians in prison. I voted to have them killed every time a vote was taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I even went to each synagogue, punished believers, and forced them to curse the name of Yeshua. In my furious rage against them, I hunted them down in cities outside Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I was carrying out these activities when I went to the city of Damascus. I had the power and authority of the chief priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty, at noon, while I was traveling, I saw a light that was brighter than the sun. The light came from the sky and shined around me and those who were with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of us fell to the ground, and I heard a voice asking me in Hebrew, ‘Saul, Saul! Why are you persecuting me? It’s hard for a mortal like you to resist God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I asked, ‘Who are you, sir?’
“The Lord answered, ‘I am Yeshua, the one you’re persecuting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stand up! I have appeared to you for a reason. I’m appointing you to be a servant and witness of what you have seen and of what I will show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will rescue you from the Jewish people and from the non-Jewish people to whom I am sending you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light and from Satan’s control to God’s. Then they will receive forgiveness for their sins and a share among God’s people who are made holy by believing in me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “At that point I did not disobey the vision I saw from heaven, King Agrippa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, I spread the message that I first told to the Jewish people in Damascus and Jerusalem and throughout the whole country of Judea. I spread the same message to non-Jewish people. Both groups were expected to change the way they thought and acted and to turn to God. I told them to do things that prove they had changed their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason the Jews took me prisoner in the temple courtyard and tried to murder me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God has been helping me to this day so that I can stand and testify to important and unimportant people. I tell them only what the prophets and Moses said would happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said that the Messiah would suffer and be the first to come back to life and would spread light to Jewish and non-Jewish people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Paul was defending himself in this way, Festus shouted, “Paul, you’re crazy! Too much education is driving you crazy!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “I’m not crazy, Your Excellency Festus. What I’m saying is true and sane.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I can easily speak to a king who knows about these things. I’m sure that none of these things has escaped his attention. None of this was done secretly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you believe them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Agrippa said to Paul, “Do you think you can quickly persuade me to become a Christian?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “I wish to God that you and everyone listening to me today would quickly and completely become as I am (except for being a prisoner).”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, the governor, Bernice, and the people who were sitting with them got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were leaving, they said to each other, “This man isn’t doing anything for which he deserves to die or be put in prison.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Agrippa told Festus, “This man could have been set free if he hadn’t appealed his case to the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was decided that we should sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were turned over to an army officer. His name was Julius, and he belonged to the emperor’s division.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We set sail on a ship from the city of Adramyttium. The ship was going to stop at ports on the coast of the province of Asia. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from the city of Thessalonica, went with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we arrived at the city of Sidon. Julius treated Paul kindly and allowed him to visit his friends and receive any care he needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leaving Sidon, we sailed on the northern side of the island of Cyprus because we were traveling against the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed along the coast of the provinces of Cilicia and Pamphylia and arrived at the city of Myra in the province of Lycia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Myra the officer found a ship from Alexandria that was on its way to Italy and put us on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were sailing slowly for a number of days. Our difficulties began along the coast of the city of Cnidus because the wind would not let us go further. So at Cape Salmone, we started to sail for the south side of the island of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We had difficulty sailing along the shore of Crete. We finally came to a port called Fair Harbors. The port was near the city of Lasea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We had lost so much time that the day of fasting had already past. Sailing was now dangerous, so Paul advised them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men, we’re going to face a disaster and heavy losses on this voyage. This disaster will cause damage to the cargo and the ship, and it will affect our lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the officer was persuaded by what the pilot and the owner of the ship said and not by what Paul said.
verses.speaker: Narrator
