verses.text: Since the harbor was not a good place to spend the winter, most of the men decided to sail from there. They hoped to reach the city of Phoenix somehow and spend the winter there. (Phoenix is a harbor that faces the southwest and northwest winds and is located on the island of Crete.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a gentle breeze began to blow from the south, the men thought their plan would work. They raised the anchor and sailed close to the shore of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon a powerful wind (called a northeaster) blew from the island.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wind carried the ship away, and we couldn’t sail against the wind. We couldn’t do anything, so we were carried along by the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As we drifted to the sheltered side of a small island called Cauda, we barely got control of the ship’s lifeboat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men pulled it up on deck. Then they passed ropes under the ship to reinforce it. Fearing that they would hit the large sandbank off the shores of Libya, they lowered the sail and were carried along by the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We continued to be tossed so violently by the storm that the next day the men began to throw the cargo overboard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day they threw the ship’s equipment overboard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a number of days we couldn’t see the sun or the stars. The storm wouldn’t let up. It was so severe that we finally began to lose any hope of coming out of it alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since hardly anyone wanted to eat, Paul stood among them and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice not to sail from Crete. You would have avoided this disaster and loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I advise you to have courage. No one will lose his life. Only the ship will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know this because an angel from the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood by me last night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel told me, ‘Don’t be afraid, Paul! You must present your case to the emperor. God has granted safety to everyone who is sailing with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So have courage, men! I trust God that everything will turn out as he told me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we will run aground on some island.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourteenth night we were still drifting through the Mediterranean Sea. About midnight the sailors suspected that we were approaching land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they threw a line with a weight on it into the water. It sank 120 feet. They waited a little while and did the same thing again. This time the line sank 90 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fearing we might hit rocks, they dropped four anchors from the back of the ship and prayed for morning to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sailors tried to escape from the ship. They let the lifeboat down into the sea and pretended they were going to lay out the anchors from the front of the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul told the officer and the soldiers, “If these sailors don’t stay on the ship, you have no hope of staying alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers cut the ropes that held the lifeboat and let it drift away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just before daybreak Paul was encouraging everyone to have something to eat. “This is the fourteenth day you have waited and have had nothing to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I’m encouraging you to eat something. Eating will help you survive, since not a hair from anyone’s head will be lost.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul said this, he took some bread, thanked God in front of everyone, broke it, and began to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone was encouraged and had something to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (There were 276 of us on the ship.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the people had eaten all they wanted, they lightened the ship by dumping the wheat into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning they couldn’t recognize the land, but they could see a bay with a beach. So they decided to try to run the ship ashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cut the anchors free and left them in the sea. At the same time they untied the ropes that held the steering oars. Then they raised the top sail to catch the wind and steered the ship to the shore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They struck a sandbar in the water and ran the ship aground. The front of the ship stuck and couldn’t be moved, while the back of the ship was broken to pieces by the force of the waves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers had a plan to kill the prisoners to keep them from swimming away and escaping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the officer wanted to save Paul, so he stopped the soldiers from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and swim ashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he ordered the rest to follow on planks or some other pieces of wood from the ship. In this way everyone got to shore safely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we were safely on shore, we found out that the island was called Malta.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who lived on the island were unusually kind to us. They made a fire and welcomed all of us around it because of the rain and the cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul gathered a bundle of brushwood and put it on the fire. The heat forced a poisonous snake out of the brushwood. The snake bit Paul’s hand and wouldn’t let go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people who lived on the island saw the snake hanging from his hand, they said to each other, “This man must be a murderer! He may have escaped from the sea, but justice won’t let him live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul shook the snake into the fire and wasn’t harmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people were waiting for him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. But after they had waited a long time and saw nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man named Publius, who was the governor of the island, had property around the area. He welcomed us and treated us kindly, and for three days we were his guests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father happened to be sick in bed. He was suffering from fever and dysentery. Paul went to him, prayed, placed his hands on him, and made him well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that had happened, other sick people on the island went to Paul and were made well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They showed respect for us in many ways, and when we were going to set sail, they put whatever we needed on board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three months we sailed on an Alexandrian ship that had spent the winter at the island. The ship had the gods Castor and Pollux carved on its front.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We stopped at the city of Syracuse and stayed there for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed from Syracuse and arrived at the city of Rhegium. The next day a south wind began to blow, and two days later we arrived at the city of Puteoli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Puteoli we discovered some believers who begged us to spend a week with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Believers in Rome heard that we were coming, so they came as far as the cities of Appius’ Market and Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and felt encouraged. So we finally arrived in the city of Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After our arrival, Paul was allowed to live by himself, but he had a soldier who guarded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three days Paul invited the most influential Jews in Rome to meet with him. When they assembled, he said to them, “Brothers, I haven’t done anything against the Jewish people or violated the customs handed down by our ancestors. Yet, I’m a prisoner from Jerusalem, and I’ve been handed over to the Roman authorities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Roman authorities cross-examined me and wanted to let me go because I was accused of nothing for which I deserved to die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews objected, I was forced to appeal my case to the emperor. That doesn’t mean I have any charges to bring against my own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s why I asked to see you and speak with you. I’m wearing these chains because of what Israel hopes for.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jewish leaders told Paul, “We haven’t received any letters from Judea about you, and no Jewish person who has come to Rome has reported or mentioned anything bad about you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we would like to hear what you think. We know that everywhere people are talking against this sect.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On a designated day a larger number of influential Jews than expected went to the place where Paul was staying. From morning until evening, Paul was explaining the kingdom of God to them. He was trying to convince them about Yeshua from Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of them were convinced by what he said, but others continued to disbelieve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews, unable to agree among themselves, left after Paul had quoted this particular passage to them: “How well the Holy Spirit spoke to your ancestors through the prophet Isaiah!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Spirit said: ‘Go to these people and say,
“You will hear clearly but never understand.
    You will see clearly but never comprehend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These people have become close-minded
    and hard of hearing.
        They have shut their eyes
            so that their eyes never see.
        Their ears never hear.
    Their minds never understand.
    And they never turn to me for healing.” ’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You need to know that God has sent his salvation to people who are not Jews. They will listen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul rented a place to live for two full years and welcomed everyone who came to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spread the message about God’s kingdom and taught very boldly about the Lord Yeshua Christ. No one stopped him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
